BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones, especially on steep sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily, this applies even in case of a small load. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 10 to 25 cm of snow will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Not yet all starting zones have released the snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry and moist avalanches are to be expected, even large ones. In the regions exposed to rain this applies in particular on very steep slopes as well as.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
70 to 110 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Up to 1600 m rain has fallen since Wednesday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation there will be only a slight decrease in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant at intermediate altitudes. They are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
As the moisture increases dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large. The avalanche danger is within the uppermost range of danger level 3 (considerable).
The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 50 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last four days above approximately 1800 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places in particular on sunny slopes. As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and rain up to approximately 2000 m the snowpack could not consolidate.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Down to 1300 m snow will fall. The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and gliding snow require caution. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large. Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As before, it is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
90 to 130 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. Up to 1800 m rain has fallen since Wednesday. The sleet gave rise to extreme moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

More frequent medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected below approximately 2600 m. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent medium-sized gliding avalanches are to be expected, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area up to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately. They are in some cases prone to triggering, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the precarious wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains generally moist. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the snowpack. The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains wet all the way through over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. Light precipitation.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Evening drizzle or sleet. Avalanche danger progressively easing.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Snow cover rapidly settling and progressively consolidating. Triggering will be possible with low overload on many steep slopes at all aspects. To the south, the entire recent snow cover rests, almost entirely, on unfrozen uncovered ground, a condition that will favor accentuated snow flow phenomena. Natural avalanches both on the ground and on the surface of large dimensions will still be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and gliding snow represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More natural avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones, especially in steep rocky terrain, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can in isolated cases reach low altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches in some places. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The moderate wind has transported some snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack will be in most cases moist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on little-used, rather lightly snow-covered northwest, north and east facing slopes. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Natural avalanches: Wet loose snow avalanches are still possible, after an overcast night especially on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday.
The easterly wind has transported some snow. Numerous medium-sized moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming. 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong in the vicinity of peaks. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Rapidly settling snowpack, with weak internal bonds. On the steep slopes at higher altitudes, releases and spontaneous releases of medium and large ground avalanches will be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Evening drizzle or sleet. Avalanche danger progressively easing.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Snow cover progressively settling and consolidating. The triggering will be possible even with a low overload, generating even large avalanches. Natural avalanche activity still possible from steep slopes not yet released, with medium-large sized phenomena.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on little-used, rather lightly snow-covered northwest, north and east facing slopes. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Natural avalanches: Some small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible, especially on very steep slopes at the base of rock walls. In the regions where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
Wet loose snow avalanches are still possible, after an overcast night especially on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The easterly wind has transported the new snow.
Today on steep shady slopes many small and medium-sized avalanches were observed.
20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong in the vicinity of peaks. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of the rain more frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are to be expected, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Friday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes.

In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall a sometimes unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Already in the early morning, dry and wet avalanches are possible. Many small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible, especially on very steep slopes at the base of rock walls. In the regions where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes medium-sized natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected in isolated cases.
Weakly bonded old snow: Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on little-used, rather lightly snow-covered northwest, north and east facing slopes. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 90 cm of snow has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m. The easterly wind has transported some snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Afternoon: On Saturday the wind will be strong. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of the rain more frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are to be expected, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Friday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes.

In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thin layers of snow resting on uncovered ground. Possible discharges of small and medium size on steep slopes at higher altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1800 m. Natural avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Natural avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially on steep slopes especially above approximately 1800 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1700 m hardly any snow is lying. The rain will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1800 m. At high altitude the avalanche danger is one level higher. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. On steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the avalanche danger is moderate (level 2).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snowpack.
